title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text:
What is Continuous Data?


Definition:
Data that represents numeric measurements or quantities

Can take any value within a range
Quantitative rather than qualitative
Often derived from measurements


Examples in Our Dataset:

Age (18-79 years)
BMI (11.4-37.3)
Cholesterol levels
Blood Sugar levels
Blood Pressure (Systolic & Diastolic)
Latitude & Longitude

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text:
Analytical Goals for Continuous Data

What questions can we answer?


🟡 Distribution - What’s the spread? Shape? Center?
⚫ Correlation - How do two variables relate to each other?


Charts we’ll learn:

Histogram
Density Plot
Scatter Plot
Box Plot (covered in Category vs. Continuous)

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text:
Setup: Load Libraries and Data


Code
# Load required libraries
library(ggplot2)    # For creating plots
library(dplyr)      # For data manipulation

# Load the dataset
data <- readxl::read_excel("../../data/PublicHealth_BP_Dataset.xlsx")

# Handle missing data: select complete cases for key numeric variables
data_clean <- data %>%
  filter(!is.na(BMI), !is.na(Cholesterol), !is.na(Age))  # Remove missing values

# Preview numeric variables
summary(data_clean %>% 
  select(Age, BMI, Cholesterol, BloodSugar, SysBP_0m, DiaBP_0m))

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text:
Histogram - Code
🟡 Goal: Distribution (show frequency across bins)


Code
# Create histogram showing age distribution
ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = Age)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30, fill = "steelblue", color = "white", alpha = 0.8) +  # 30 bins
  labs(title = "Distribution of Patient Ages",
       x = "Age (years)", y = "Frequency (Number of Patients)") +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +  # Serif font for professional look
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
        axis.text = element_text(size = 10))




bins = 30 divides the data into 30 equal-width intervals
Adjust bins to find optimal visualization (too few = loss of detail, too many = noise)

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text: Histogram - Plot

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text:
How to Read Histograms
Using the previous plot:

OBSERVATION: - Distribution appears roughly uniform across age range - Ages range from ~18 to ~79 years - No clear peak (not normally distributed) - Relatively even frequency across all age groups - No obvious outliers or gaps
INTERPRETATION: - Study successfully recruited across broad age spectrum - No age group dominates the sample - Good representation for age-stratified analysis - Uniform distribution suggests deliberate balanced recruitment
IMPLICATIONS: - Results generalizable across adult age range - Can analyze age as continuous variable or create age groups - Sufficient sample in all age ranges for subgroup analysis
ACTIONS: - Consider age as covariate in treatment analysis - May want to create age categories (e.g., 18-40, 41-60, 61+) - Check if age interacts with treatment effect

:::

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text:
Histogram with Mean/Median Lines - Code
🟡 Goal: Distribution with central tendency markers


Code
# Calculate summary statistics
age_mean <- mean(data_clean$Age, na.rm = TRUE)  # Calculate mean
age_median <- median(data_clean$Age, na.rm = TRUE)  # Calculate median

# Create histogram with reference lines
ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = Age)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30, fill = "steelblue", color = "white", alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = age_mean), color = "red", 
             linetype = "dashed", size = 1) +  # Add mean line
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = age_median), color = "darkgreen", 
             linetype = "solid", size = 1) +  # Add median line
  annotate("text", x = age_mean + 5, y = 15, 
           label = paste("Mean =", round(age_mean, 1)), 
           color = "red", family = "serif", size = 4) +  # Label mean
  annotate("text", x = age_median - 5, y = 15, 
           label = paste("Median =", round(age_median, 1)), 
           color = "darkgreen", family = "serif", size = 4) +  # Label median
  labs(title = "Age Distribution with Mean and Median",
       x = "Age (years)", y = "Frequency") +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"))

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text: Histogram with Statistics - Plot

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text:
Density Plot - Code
🟡 Goal: Distribution (smooth curve, easier to compare)


Code
# Create smooth density plot for BMI
ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = BMI)) +
  geom_density(fill = "coral", alpha = 0.6, color = "darkred", size = 1) +  # Smooth density
  labs(title = "Density Distribution of BMI",
       x = "Body Mass Index (BMI)", y = "Density") +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12))



Density plots smooth out histogram bins, showing underlying distribution shape Area under curve = 1 (100%)

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text: Density Plot - Plot

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text:
Scatter Plot - Code
⚫ Goal: Correlation between two continuous variables


Code
# Create scatter plot showing BMI vs. Cholesterol relationship
ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = BMI, y = Cholesterol)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6, color = "darkblue", size = 3) +  # Add semi-transparent points
  labs(title = "Relationship between BMI and Cholesterol",
       x = "Body Mass Index (BMI)", y = "Cholesterol (mg/dL)") +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12))




alpha = 0.6 makes points semi-transparent to show overlapping
Look for patterns: positive correlation, negative, or no relationship

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text: Scatter Plot - Plot

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text:
How to Read Scatter Plots
Using the previous plot:

OBSERVATION: - Points scattered across the plot area - No clear linear pattern visible - BMI ranges from ~15 to ~37 - Cholesterol ranges from ~120 to ~290 - Some clustering but no strong trend
INTERPRETATION: - Weak or no correlation between BMI and Cholesterol in this sample - Relationship appears to be random/independent - Both variables vary independently - No obvious outliers or extreme cases
IMPLICATIONS: - BMI alone may not predict cholesterol levels - Other factors likely influence cholesterol (diet, genetics, medication) - Cannot use BMI as sole predictor of cholesterol risk - Need multivariate analysis for better understanding
CRITICAL WARNING: - Correlation ≠ Causation - Even if correlation existed, wouldn’t prove causal relationship - Always consider confounding variables - Use domain knowledge alongside statistical patterns

:::

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text:
Scatter Plot with Categories - Code
⚫ Goal: Correlation + Compare groups


Code
# Scatter plot colored by Treatment Group
ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m, color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7, size = 3) +  # Color points by group
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Control" = "#E74C3C", 
                                 "Intervention" = "#3498DB"),
                     name = "Treatment Group") +  # Custom colors
  labs(title = "Baseline Systolic BP by Age and Treatment Group",
       x = "Age (years)", 
       y = "Systolic Blood Pressure (mmHg)") +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
        legend.position = "right")

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text: Scatter Plot with Categories - Plot

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text:
Continuous Plots - Summary









Chart Type
Goal
When to Use
Code Complexity




Histogram
🟡 Distribution
Show frequency distribution, find shape
Simple (3-6 lines)


Histogram + Stats
🟡 Distribution
Add mean/median for context
Medium (8-12 lines)


Density Plot
🟡 Distribution
Smooth distribution, compare groups
Simple (3-6 lines)


Scatter Plot
⚫ Correlation
Show relationship between 2 variables
Simple (3-6 lines)


Scatter + Color
⚫ Correlation + Groups
Compare correlations across groups
Medium (6-8 lines)

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text:
Common Distribution Shapes


Normal (Bell Curve) - Symmetric around mean - Mean ≈ Median - Example: Heights
Right Skewed - Long tail to the right - Mean > Median
- Example: Income
Left Skewed - Long tail to the left - Mean < Median - Example: Age at retirement

Bimodal - Two peaks - Two distinct groups - Example: Customer segments
Uniform - Flat distribution - All values equally likely - Example: Random numbers
Outliers - Extreme values - Check for data errors - May need special handling

title: Continuous Plots - BASIC
text:
Key Takeaways


Remember:

Choose bins wisely - test different values for histograms
Density vs. Histogram - density better for comparing groups
Scatter plots reveal relationships - but don’t assume causation
Alpha transparency - helps see overlapping points
Always handle missing data - document your approach

Common Mistakes:

Too many/few histogram bins
Not handling outliers
Assuming correlation = causation
Ignoring data transformations when needed
Poor color choices for scatter plot groups

title: Dashboards - ADVANCED

Topics Covered

Dashboard layout principles
Shiny app structure

plotly interactivity
flexdashboard framework

Goal: Create interactive analytical tools

title: Dashboards - ADVANCED
text:
Dashboard Layout Principles


F-Pattern Layout:

Top row: Key metrics (KPIs)
Left column: Filters/controls
Center: Main visualizations
Right: Secondary insights

Golden Rules:

Most important info top-left
Limit to 5-7 visualizations
Consistent color scheme
Clear hierarchy


Example Structure:
┌─────────────────────────────┐
│ KPI 1  │ KPI 2  │ KPI 3     │
├────────┼────────┼───────────┤
│ Filter │ Main Chart         │
│ Panel  │                    │
│        ├────────────────────┤
│        │ Secondary Charts   │
└────────┴────────────────────┘

title: Dashboards - ADVANCED
text:
flexdashboard Structure


Code
---
title: "Health Dashboard"
output:
  flexdashboard::flex_dashboard:
    orientation: rows
    vertical_layout: fill
---

# Page 1 {data-icon="fa-chart-bar"}

## Row 1 {data-height=100}

### KPI 1
valueBox(150, caption = "Total Patients", icon = "fa-users")

### KPI 2  
valueBox(85, caption = "% Adherence", icon = "fa-check", 
        color = ifelse(85 > 80, "success", "warning"))

## Row 2

### Chart 1
plot_ly(data, x = ~x, y = ~y, type = "scatter")

### Chart 2
ggplotly(ggplot(data, aes(x, y)) + geom_bar())

title: Dashboards - ADVANCED
Dashboards - ADVANCED
Dashboards - ADVANCED
text:
plotly Interactivity


Code
library(plotly)

# Convert ggplot to interactive
p <- ggplot(health_data, aes(x = BMI_0m, y = SysBP_0m, 
                             color = Gender,
                             text = paste("ID:", PatientID))) +
  geom_point()

ggplotly(p, tooltip = c("text", "x", "y"))

# Native plotly with custom hover
plot_ly(health_data, x = ~BMI_0m, y = ~SysBP_0m,
       color = ~Gender,
       type = "scatter", mode = "markers",
       hovertemplate = paste(
         "<b>Patient ID:</b> %{text}<br>",
         "<b>BMI:</b> %{x:.1f}<br>",
         "<b>BP:</b> %{y:.0f}<br>",
         "<extra></extra>"
       ),
       text = ~PatientID)


Hover, zoom, pan, select automatically

Optimize Shiny Apps:

Cache expensive computations



Code
cached_data <- memoise::memoise(function(param) {
  # Expensive calculation
  expensive_function(param)
})



Use renderCachedPlot for static plots
Limit reactive dependencies
Use DT package for large tables
Deploy efficiently (shinyapps.io, Docker)

title: Network - ADVANCED
text:
Topics Covered

Community detection algorithms
Centrality measures visualization
Network statistics

Goal: Advanced network insights

title: Network - ADVANCED
text: Setup

title: Network - ADVANCED
text:
Community Detection - Code


Code
# Detect communities (Louvain algorithm)
communities <- cluster_louvain(as.undirected(net))

# Add to network
V(net)$community <- membership(communities)

# Visualize
ggraph(net, layout = "fr") +
  geom_edge_link(alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_node_point(aes(color = factor(community)), size = 5) +
  geom_node_text(aes(label = name), repel = TRUE, size = 3) +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1", name = "Community") +
  labs(title = "Network Communities (Louvain)") +
  theme_void()


Identifies provider groups/clusters

title: Network - ADVANCED
text:
Centrality Measures - Code


Code
# Calculate multiple centralities
V(net)$degree <- degree(net)
V(net)$betweenness <- betweenness(net, normalized = TRUE)
V(net)$closeness <- closeness(net, normalized = TRUE)
V(net)$eigenvector <- eigen_centrality(net)$vector

# Plot by importance
ggraph(net, layout = "kk") +
  geom_edge_link(alpha = 0.2) +
  geom_node_point(aes(size = betweenness, color = degree)) +
  geom_node_text(aes(label = name, size = betweenness),
                repel = TRUE) +
  scale_color_viridis_c() +
  labs(title = "Provider Centrality Measures",
       subtitle = "Size = Betweenness | Color = Degree") +
  theme_void()

title: Network - ADVANCED
text:
Network Statistics Table


Code
# Calculate network metrics
stats <- data.frame(
  Metric = c("Nodes", "Edges", "Density", "Avg Path Length",
            "Clustering Coef", "Modularity"),
  Value = c(
    vcount(net),
    ecount(net),
    round(edge_density(net), 3),
    round(mean_distance(net), 2),
    round(transitivity(net), 3),
    round(modularity(communities), 3)
  )
)

knitr::kable(stats, caption = "Network Statistics")


Quantitative network description

title: Network - ADVANCED
text:
Bipartite Network - Code


Code
# Create bipartite: Patients <-> Providers
bipartite_edges <- network_data %>%
  select(from = PatientID, to = ReferringProvider) %>%
  mutate(from = paste0("P", from))  # Prefix patients

bp_net <- graph_from_data_frame(bipartite_edges, directed = FALSE)
V(bp_net)$type <- grepl("^P", V(bp_net)$name)  # Patient = TRUE

ggraph(bp_net, layout = "bipartite") +
  geom_edge_link(alpha = 0.1) +
  geom_node_point(aes(color = type), size = 3) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Provider" = "blue",
                               "Patient" = "orange"),
                    labels = c("Provider", "Patient")) +
  labs(title = "Patient-Provider Bipartite Network") +
  theme_void()

title: Network - ADVANCED
text:
Dynamic Network (Time-based)


Code
# Split network by time periods
network_t1 <- network_data %>%
  filter(TimePoint == "0m") %>%
  graph_from_data_frame()

network_t2 <- network_data %>%
  filter(TimePoint == "6m") %>%
  graph_from_data_frame()

# Compare side-by-side
library(patchwork)
p1 <- ggraph(network_t1) + geom_edge_link() + 
      geom_node_point() + labs(title = "Month 0")
p2 <- ggraph(network_t2) + geom_edge_link() + 
      geom_node_point() + labs(title = "Month 6")

p1 + p2


Shows network evolution

title: Network - ADVANCED
text:
Summary
Advanced network techniques:

Community detection - find clusters
Centrality measures - identify key nodes
Network statistics - quantitative metrics
Bipartite networks - two node types
Dynamic networks - temporal changes

title: Category vs Continuous - ADVANCED
text:
Topics Covered

Effect plots (model-based)
Interaction plots
Marginal effects
Bayesian credible intervals
Mixed effects visualization

Goal: Show complex statistical relationships

title: Category vs Continuous - ADVANCED
text: Setup

title: Category vs Continuous - ADVANCED
text:
Interaction Plot - Code


Code
# Fit model with interaction
model <- lm(SysBP_6m ~ TreatmentGroup * Gender + Age + BMI_0m,
           data = health_data)

# Plot interaction
library(interactions)
interact_plot(model, pred = TreatmentGroup, modx = Gender,
             interval = TRUE, int.width = 0.95) +
  labs(title = "Treatment Effect by Gender",
       y = "Predicted Systolic BP at 6 months") +
  theme_minimal()


Shows if treatment effect differs by gender

title: Category vs Continuous - ADVANCED
text:
Marginal Effects Plot


Code
library(ggeffects)
# Get predicted values
effects <- ggpredict(model, terms = c("Age [all]", "TreatmentGroup"))

plot(effects) +
  labs(title = "Age Effect on BP by Treatment Group",
       x = "Age (years)", y = "Predicted BP") +
  theme_minimal()


Model-based predictions with confidence bands

title: Category vs Continuous - ADVANCED
text:
Forest Plot (Effect Sizes)


Code
library(broom)
# Get coefficients
coef_data <- tidy(model, conf.int = TRUE) %>%
  filter(term != "(Intercept)")

ggplot(coef_data, aes(x = estimate, y = term)) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  geom_errorbarh(aes(xmin = conf.low, xmax = conf.high),
                height = 0.2) +
  labs(title = "Regression Coefficients with 95% CI",
       x = "Effect on Systolic BP") +
  theme_minimal()


Standard in medical research

title: Category vs Continuous - ADVANCED
text:
Raincloud by Multiple Groups


Code
library(ggdist)
health_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(TreatmentGroup), !is.na(Gender)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Gender, y = SysBP_6m, fill = TreatmentGroup)) +
  stat_halfeye(position = position_dodge(width = 0.5),
              adjust = 0.5, width = 0.3) +
  geom_boxplot(width = 0.1, outlier.shape = NA,
              position = position_dodge(width = 0.5)) +
  facet_wrap(~ TreatmentGroup) +
  theme_minimal()


Comprehensive view of nested groups

title: Category vs Continuous - ADVANCED
text:
Bayesian Credible Intervals


Code
library(rstanarm)
# Bayesian model (conceptual)
bayes_model <- stan_glm(SysBP_6m ~ TreatmentGroup + Age,
                       data = health_data,
                       prior = normal(0, 2.5))

# Plot posterior distributions
plot(bayes_model, prob = 0.95) +
  labs(title = "Bayesian Coefficient Estimates")


Full uncertainty quantification

Summary

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text:
What We’ll Learn - Advanced


Complex Categorical Structures:

Treemaps (hierarchical proportions)
Sunburst charts (circular hierarchies)
Dendrograms (clustering)
Marimekko charts (two-way composition)
Waffle charts (unit visualization)


Analytical Goals:

🔴 Part of Whole - Hierarchical composition
🟢 Ranking - Within hierarchies
⚫ Correlation - Category associations
🟡 Distribution - Nested patterns

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text:
Setup Code


Code
# Load required packages
library(readxl)
library(tidyverse)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(treemapify)  # For treemaps
library(sunburstR)   # For sunburst charts
library(ggmosaic)    # For mosaic plots

# Load dataset
health_data <- read_excel("../../data/PublicHealth_BP_Dataset.xlsx")

# Create hierarchical data
hierarchical_data <- health_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(Region), !is.na(Gender), !is.na(SmokingStatus)) %>%
  count(Region, Gender, SmokingStatus, name = "count")

# Create theme
theme_custom <- function() {
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    text = element_text(family = "serif", size = 12),
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 11, hjust = 0.5),
    legend.position = "bottom"
  )
}

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text:
Treemap - Code

Purpose: Show hierarchical part-to-whole relationships
Goal: 🔴 Part of Whole + 🟢 Ranking


Code
# Prepare data for treemap
treemap_data <- health_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(Region), !is.na(TreatmentGroup)) %>%
  count(Region, TreatmentGroup, name = "count") %>%
  mutate(label = paste0(TreatmentGroup, "\n(n=", count, ")"))

# Create treemap
ggplot(treemap_data, aes(area = count, fill = Region, 
                         label = label, subgroup = Region)) +
  geom_treemap() +
  geom_treemap_subgroup_border(color = "white", size = 3) +
  geom_treemap_subgroup_text(
    place = "center",
    grow = TRUE,
    alpha = 0.5,
    color = "black",
    fontface = "bold",
    size = 18
  ) +
  geom_treemap_text(
    color = "white",
    place = "center",
    size = 10,
    grow = FALSE
  ) +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") +
  labs(title = "Patient Distribution by Region and Treatment",
       subtitle = "Rectangle size proportional to patient count",
       fill = "Region") +
  theme_custom() +
  theme(legend.position = "right")

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text: Treemap - Output

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text:
Interpreting Treemaps


Key Features:

Size = Quantity - Larger rectangles = more patients
Color = Category - Each region has its own color
Hierarchy - Region (outer) → Treatment (inner)
Space-efficient - Uses all available area

Best Practices:

Limit to 2-3 hierarchy levels
Use clear labels
Consistent color scheme
Consider interactivity for complex trees


Our Treemap Shows:

East region largest overall

Most patients

Within each region treatment distribution visible

Relative sizes easy to compare

Quick identification of smallest/largest segments
Hierarchical structure immediately clear

Region → Treatment breakdown


Advantage: Efficient use of space compared to nested pie charts

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text:
Sunburst Chart - Code

Purpose: Radial hierarchical visualization
Goal: 🔴 Part of Whole (circular)


Code
# Prepare data in required format for sunburst
# Format: path-count pairs
sunburst_data <- health_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(Region), !is.na(Gender), !is.na(SmokingStatus)) %>%
  count(Region, Gender, SmokingStatus) %>%
  mutate(path = paste(Region, Gender, SmokingStatus, sep = "-")) %>%
  select(path, n)

# Create sunburst chart
sunburst(
  data = sunburst_data,
  count = TRUE,
  legend = list(w = 150, h = 25, s = 5, t = 25),
  breadcrumb = list(w = 0, h = 25, s = 5, t = 10),
  colors = list(
    range = c("#E41A1C", "#377EB8", "#4DAF4A", "#984EA3",
             "#FF7F00", "#FFFF33", "#A65628", "#F781BF")
  ),
  withD3 = TRUE,
  width = "100%",
  height = 500
)


Note: Sunburst creates interactive HTML widget. For static, use ggplot2 alternative.
Static Alternative (next slide):

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text:
Sunburst Alternative: Radial Bar - Code



Code
# Create radial bar plot (sunburst alternative)
radial_data <- health_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(Region), !is.na(SmokingStatus)) %>%
  count(Region, SmokingStatus) %>%
  group_by(Region) %>%
  mutate(
    percentage = n / sum(n) * 100,
    id = paste(Region, SmokingStatus, sep = "-")
  )

ggplot(radial_data, aes(x = Region, y = n, fill = SmokingStatus)) +
  geom_col(width = 1, color = "white", size = 0.5) +
  coord_polar() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Never" = "#00A087", 
                              "Former" = "#3C5488",
                              "Current" = "#DC0000")) +
  labs(title = "Smoking Status Distribution by Region (Radial)",
       subtitle = "Each segment shows proportion within region",
       fill = "Smoking Status") +
  theme_custom() +
  theme(
    axis.text.y = element_blank(),
    axis.title = element_blank(),
    panel.grid = element_blank()
  )

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text: Radial Bar - Output

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text:
Marimekko Chart - Code

Purpose: Two-way composition (varying column widths)
Goal: 🔴 Part of Whole (two dimensions)


Code
# Prepare data for Marimekko
marimekko_data <- health_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(Region), !is.na(TreatmentGroup)) %>%
  count(Region, TreatmentGroup) %>%
  group_by(Region) %>%
  mutate(
    region_total = sum(n),
    pct_in_region = n / region_total * 100
  ) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  mutate(
    region_pct = region_total / sum(region_total) * 100,
    cumsum_region = cumsum(region_pct) - region_pct / 2
  )

# Create Marimekko chart
ggplot(marimekko_data, aes(x = Region, y = pct_in_region, 
                           fill = TreatmentGroup, width = region_pct)) +
  geom_col(position = "stack", color = "white", size = 0.5) +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set1") +
  labs(title = "Treatment Distribution by Region (Marimekko)",
       subtitle = "Column width = regional patient share | Height = treatment proportion",
       x = "Region",
       y = "Percentage within Region",
       fill = "Treatment") +
  theme_custom() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 0))

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text: Marimekko Chart - Output

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text:
Interpreting Marimekko Charts

Unique Features:


Two dimensions of composition

Width would represent one variable’s total
Height shows breakdown within that category

Space = Area

Total area of each segment = actual count contribution

Compare both dimensions simultaneously

More information dense than standard stacked bars


Our Chart:

Treatment distribution fairly consistent across regions
All regions show similar proportions of each treatment
Visual balance suggests good randomization

When to use: Two categorical variables where both totals and proportions matter

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text:
Waffle Chart - Code

Purpose: Unit-based visualization (each square = fixed count)
Goal: 🔴 Part of Whole (intuitive units)


Code
# Prepare data (each unit = 10 patients)
waffle_data <- health_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(TreatmentGroup)) %>%
  count(TreatmentGroup) %>%
  mutate(squares = round(n / 10))  # 1 square = 10 patients

# Create waffle chart
waffle_expanded <- waffle_data %>%
  rowwise() %>%
  mutate(id = list(1:squares)) %>%
  unnest(id) %>%
  mutate(square_id = row_number(),
         x = (square_id - 1) %% 10,   # 10 rows
         y = (square_id - 1) %/% 10)

# Plot with ggplot2
ggplot(waffle_expanded, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_tile(color = "white", size = 0.5) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Treatment A" = "#E41A1C",
                               "Treatment B" = "#377EB8",
                               "Control"     = "#4DAF4A")) +
  coord_equal() +
  labs(title = "Patient Distribution by Treatment Group",
       x = "1 square = 10 patients",
       y = NULL) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    axis.text.y = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks = element_blank(),
    text = element_text(family = "serif", size = 12),
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5)
  )

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text: Waffle Chart - Output

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text:
Interpreting Waffle Charts

Why Waffle Charts Work:


Intuitive unit representation

Each square = fixed count (e.g., 10 patients)
Easy to count and compare

Avoid pie chart problems

No angles to judge
Better for exact comparisons

Visual impact

Engaging and memorable
Good for presentations and infographics


Our Chart:

Treatment groups balanced
Control group has similar size
Each square represents 10 patients
Visual counting easier than interpreting angles

When to use: Small to medium datasets, need visual impact

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text:
Dendrogram - Code

Purpose: Show hierarchical clustering of categories
Goal: ⚫ Correlation + hierarchical structure


Code
# Calculate dissimilarity matrix for regions based on health metrics
region_profiles <- health_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(Region)) %>%
  group_by(Region) %>%
  summarise(
    mean_bp = mean(SysBP_0m, na.rm = TRUE),
    mean_chol = mean(Cholesterol_0m, na.rm = TRUE),
    mean_bmi = mean(BMI_0m, na.rm = TRUE),
    pct_smokers = mean(SmokingStatus == "Current", na.rm = TRUE) * 100
  ) %>%
  column_to_rownames("Region")

# Scale variables
region_scaled <- scale(region_profiles)

# Hierarchical clustering
hc <- hclust(dist(region_scaled), method = "ward.D2")

# Plot dendrogram
library(ggdendro)
ggdendrogram(hc, rotate = FALSE, theme_dendro = FALSE) +
  labs(title = "Hierarchical Clustering of Regions by Health Profiles",
       subtitle = "Based on BP, cholesterol, BMI, and smoking rates",
       x = "Region",
       y = "Distance (Ward's method)") +
  theme_custom() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 0))

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text: Dendrogram - Output

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text:
Interpreting Dendrograms


Reading Dendrograms:

Height = Dissimilarity
Branches joining lower = more similar
Clusters formed by cutting at height
Leaf = Individual category

Method Matters:

Ward’s - Minimizes within-cluster variance
Complete - Maximum distance
Average - Mean distance between clusters


Our Dendrogram:

East and North most similar

Join at lowest height
Similar health profiles

South different from North/East

Joins at higher level

West most distinct

Joins last, highest dissimilarity


Use Case: Identifying similar market segments, patient groups

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text:
Chart Selection Guide










Chart Type
Goal
Best For
Complexity




Treemap
🔴 Part of Whole
Hierarchical proportions, space-efficient
Medium


Sunburst
🔴 Part of Whole
Multi-level hierarchies, interactive
High


Marimekko
🔴 Part of Whole
Two-way composition
Medium-High


Waffle
🔴 Part of Whole
Small datasets, visual impact
Easy-Medium


Dendrogram
⚫ Correlation
Category clustering, similarity
Medium-High



Pro Tip: Advanced charts require more explanation - include clear legends and labels

title: Categorical - ADVANCED
text:
Common Mistakes


Too many categories in treemap/sunburst

Solution: Filter to top N categories or aggregate small ones

Poor color choices making comparisons hard

Solution: Use consistent, meaningful color schemes

Missing context in dendrograms

Solution: Explain clustering method and distance metric

Waffle charts with inappropriate units

Solution: Choose unit size that creates 50-200 squares

Marimekko without clear labels

Solution: Add annotations explaining width/height meanings

Interactive charts not working in static reports

Solution: Provide static alternatives or export images

text:

What You’ve Learned:


Treemaps efficiently show hierarchical proportions
Sunburst charts display circular hierarchies
Marimekko charts reveal two-way compositions
Waffle charts provide intuitive unit-based views
Dendrograms identify category similarities

Key Principle:

title: Plotting Tools
text:
Plotting Tools
This chapter introduces various tools and libraries available in R for creating visualizations. It covers base R plotting functions, as well as popular packages like ggplot2 and lattice, which offer advanced capabilities for creating complex and customizable plots.

title: Debugging Plots
text: Debugging plots are essential tools for diagnosing issues in data visualization and analysis. They help identify problems such as incorrect data representation, scaling issues, or unexpected patterns in the data. In this guide, we will explore various techniques and tools for creating effective debugging plots.

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Module 4 Overview
Previously: - Module 1: Foundations & Geoms - Module 2: Aesthetics, Faceting & Themes - Module 3: Colors, Scales & Custom Themes
This Module (FINAL): - Complex visualizations with progressive builds - Advanced composition techniques - Exporting and reproducibility - Limitations of ggplot2 - Best practices and common pitfalls - Workshop summary

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Setup


Code
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(readxl)
library(ggthemes)
library(paletteer)
library(patchwork)
# remotes::install_github("haleyjeppson/ggmosaic")
library(ggmosaic)  # For mosaic plots

# Load data with all transformations
bp_data <- read_excel("../../data/PublicHealth_BP_Dataset.xlsx") %>%
  mutate(
    SysBP_Change = SysBP_6m - SysBP_0m,
    DiaBP_Change = DiaBP_6m - DiaBP_0m,
    AgeGroup = cut(Age, breaks = c(0, 30, 50, 65, 100),
                   labels = c("18-30", "31-50", "51-65", "65+")),
    Hypertension_Baseline = ifelse(SysBP_0m >= 140 | DiaBP_0m >= 90, 
                                   "Hypertensive", "Normal"),
    BMI_Category = cut(BMI, breaks = c(0, 18.5, 25, 30, 100),
                       labels = c("Underweight", "Normal", "Overweight", "Obese"))
  )

# Time series
bp_time <- bp_data %>%
  select(PatientID, TreatmentGroup, SysBP_0m, SysBP_3m, SysBP_6m) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("SysBP"),
               names_to = "Time", values_to = "SysBP") %>%
  mutate(Months = as.numeric(gsub("SysBP_|m", "", Time)))

# Summary data
bp_summary <- bp_time %>%
  group_by(TreatmentGroup, Months) %>%
  summarise(Mean_SysBP = mean(SysBP, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")

ci_data <- bp_time %>%
  group_by(TreatmentGroup, Months) %>%
  summarise(Mean = mean(SysBP), SE = sd(SysBP) / sqrt(n()), .groups = "drop")

# Custom theme from Module 3
theme_clinical_report <- function(base_size = 12, base_family = "serif") {
  theme_bw(base_size = base_size, base_family = base_family) +
  theme(
    text = element_text(family = base_family),
    plot.title = element_text(size = base_size * 1.3, face = "bold", 
                              hjust = 0.5, margin = margin(b = 10)),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = base_size * 1.1, hjust = 0.5,
                                 color = "gray30", margin = margin(b = 15)),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = base_size * 0.9, hjust = 1,
                                face = "italic", color = "gray50"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = base_size * 1.1, face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(size = base_size * 0.9, color = "gray20"),
    axis.line = element_line(color = "black", linewidth = 0.5),
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "gray90", linewidth = 0.5),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.border = element_rect(color = "gray40", fill = NA, linewidth = 1),
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white"),
    legend.position = "bottom",
    legend.title = element_text(size = base_size, face = "bold"),
    legend.text = element_text(size = base_size * 0.9),
    legend.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = NA),
    legend.key = element_rect(fill = "white", color = NA),
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = NA)
  )
}

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Progressive Build: Starting Simple


Code
# Step 1: Basic plot
p_base <- ggplot(bp_data, 
                 aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
                     color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6, size = 2)

p_base

p_trend

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Progressive Build: Final Polish




Code
# Step 4: Final customization
p_final <- p_themed +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("Control" = "steelblue",
               "Intervention" = "darkred"),
    name = "Treatment Group") +
  labs(title = "Age vs Baseline Systolic BP",
       subtitle = "With linear trend lines",
       x = "Age (years)",
       y = "Systolic BP (mmHg)",
       caption = "n=200 patients")

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Multi-Geom Plot: Points + Line + Ribbon




Code
ggplot(ci_data, 
       aes(x = Months, y = Mean,
           color = TreatmentGroup,
           fill = TreatmentGroup)) +
  # Confidence band
  geom_ribbon(aes(ymin = Mean - 1.96*SE,
                  ymax = Mean + 1.96*SE),
              alpha = 0.2, color = NA) +
  # Trend line
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.5) +
  # Data points
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("steelblue", "darkred")) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c("steelblue", "darkred"))

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Combining Geoms Strategically




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = AgeGroup, y = SysBP_Change,
           fill = TreatmentGroup)) +
  # Individual points with jitter
  geom_jitter(aes(color = TreatmentGroup),
              alpha = 0.3, width = 0.2,
              size = 1.5, show.legend = FALSE) +
  # Box plot overlay
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.6, outlier.shape = NA) +
  # Add mean as point
  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "point",
               size = 3, color = "black", shape = 18)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Publication-Ready Plot: All Elements


Code
publication_plot <- ggplot(bp_data, 
                           aes(x = BMI, y = Cholesterol,
                               color = Hypertension_Baseline)) +
  # Data layer
  geom_point(size = 2.5, alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE, linewidth = 1.2) +
  
  # Scales
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("Normal" = "forestgreen", "Hypertensive" = "darkred"),
    name = "Baseline BP Status") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(15, 40, 5)) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(100, 300, 50)) +
  
  # Labels
  labs(
    title = "Relationship Between BMI and Cholesterol",
    subtitle = "Stratified by baseline hypertension status",
    x = "Body Mass Index (kg/m²)",
    y = "Total Cholesterol (mg/dL)",
    caption = "Data: Public Health BP Dataset | n=200 patients | Linear regression with 95% CI"
  ) +
  
  # Theme
  theme_clinical_report(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = c(0.85, 0.15),
    legend.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = "black", linewidth = 0.5)
  )

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text: Publication-Ready Output

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Layer Ordering Matters




Code
# Smooth UNDER points
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +  # First
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5)        # Second










Code
# Smooth OVER points
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +      # First
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")     # Second

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Coordinate Systems: coord_flip()




Code
region_summary <- bp_data %>%
  group_by(Region) %>%
  summarise(Mean_SysBP = mean(SysBP_0m), .groups = "drop")

ggplot(region_summary, 
       aes(x = reorder(Region, Mean_SysBP),
           y = Mean_SysBP, fill = Region)) +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip()



Useful for: Long category names, horizontal bar charts

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
ggsave(): Saving Plots


Code
# Create a plot
my_plot <- ggplot(bp_data, aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m, color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_point() + theme_minimal()

# Save the plot
ggsave(
  filename = "blood_pressure_analysis.png",
  plot = my_plot,
  width = 10, height = 6, units = "in",
  dpi = 300)




filename: File path and name with extension
plot: ggplot object (defaults to last plot displayed)
width, height: Dimensions
units: “in” (inches), “cm”, “mm”, “px”
dpi: Resolution (72 = screen, 300 = print quality, 600 = high-res print)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Supported File Formats


Raster (Pixel-based):

PNG - Best for web, presentations
JPEG - Photos, small file size
TIFF - High-quality archival



Code
ggsave("plot.png", dpi = 300)
ggsave("plot.jpg", dpi = 150)
ggsave("plot.tiff", dpi = 600)



Vector (Scalable):

PDF - Publications, printing
SVG - Web, editing in Illustrator
EPS - Legacy publications



Code
ggsave("plot.pdf", width = 8, 
       height = 6)
ggsave("plot.svg")
ggsave("plot.eps")

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Choosing the Right Format









Format
Use Case
Pros
Cons




PNG
Web, presentations, reports
Lossless, transparent background
Large files


PDF
Publications, printing
Scalable, professional
Requires PDF reader


SVG
Web, further editing
Scalable, editable
Not all software supports


JPEG
Web (photos)
Small files
Lossy compression


TIFF
Archival, high-res
Lossless, high quality
Very large files




Recommendation: Use PDF for publications, PNG (300 dpi) for presentations/reports

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Reproducibility Best Practices


Set seed for random elements (jitter, sampling)



Code
set.seed(123)



Document R and package versions



Code
sessionInfo()



Use relative paths, not absolute



Code
# Good: read_excel("data/bp_data.xlsx")
# Bad:  read_excel("C:/Users/John/Documents/data/bp_data.xlsx")



Version control with Git/GitHub
Use R Projects for project organization

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
What ggplot2 Cannot Do Well
While ggplot2 is powerful, it has limitations:


Mosaic plots / Marimekko charts - Better with ggmosaic or base R mosaicplot()
3D plots - Not natively supported, use plotly or rgl
Network graphs - Use ggraph or igraph
Interactive plots - Limited, need plotly::ggplotly() or ggiraph
Sankey diagrams - Use ggalluvial or networkD3
Circular plots (beyond polar) - Use circlize
Very complex statistical diagrams - May need specialized packages

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Mosaic Plots


ggplot2 cannot easily create mosaic plots


Code
# Use ggmosaic package instead
library(ggmosaic)

ggplot(bp_data) +
  geom_mosaic(
    aes(x = product(TreatmentGroup, 
                    SmokingStatus),
        fill = TreatmentGroup))



Or use base R mosaicplot() for traditional mosaic plots

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
When to Use Alternatives



Need
ggplot2 Solution
Better Alternative




Mosaic plots
❌ Not supported
ggmosaic, base mosaicplot()


3D visualization
❌ Not supported
plotly, rgl, plot3D


Network graphs
❌ Not supported
ggraph, igraph, visNetwork


Interactive plots
Limited
plotly, ggiraph, highcharter


Animated plots
Via gganimate
gganimate, plotly


Sankey diagrams
❌ Not supported
ggalluvial, networkD3


Circular plots
Limited (coord_polar)
circlize


Geographic maps
Basic
leaflet, tmap, sf

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
ggplot2 Extensions Ecosystem
The good news: The ggplot2 ecosystem is vast!


ggmosaic - Mosaic plots
gganimate - Animation
ggraph - Network/tree diagrams
ggalluvial - Sankey/alluvial diagrams
ggiraph - Interactive graphics
patchwork / cowplot - Combining plots
ggridges - Ridge line plots
ggrepel - Smart label placement
ggforce - Additional geoms and stats
ggsci - Scientific journal color palettes



See: https://exts.ggplot2.tidyverse.org/ for comprehensive list

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Common Pitfalls to Avoid


Mapping constants inside aes() - Use fixed values outside aes
Too many aesthetics - Limit to 3-4 visual encodings max
Poor color choices - Always test for colorblind accessibility
Overplotting - Use alpha, jitter, or facets
Misleading axes - Always start at zero for bar charts
Too much clutter - Remove unnecessary grid lines, legends, or decorations
Inconsistent themes - Use theme_set() for consistency
Ignoring aspect ratios - Consider final output dimensions
Not saving properly - Use appropriate format and resolution
Forgetting reproducibility - Set seed, document packages

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Best Practices Checklist
Before finalizing visualizations:


Color: Use colorblind-friendly palettes (viridis, ColorBrewer)
Contrast: Ensure sufficient contrast between elements
Text size: Minimum 10pt for body text, 12pt+ for titles
Redundancy: Don’t rely on color alone (use shape, pattern, labels)
Simplicity: Remove unnecessary elements
Labels: Clear, descriptive axis labels and titles
Alt text: Provide text description for screen readers
Print: Test in grayscale/black & white
Simulation: Test with colorblind simulator
Font: Use readable fonts (avoid decorative fonts)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
The ggplot2 Building Process


Code
ggplot(data, aes(x = var1, y = var2)) +           # 1. Data + Aesthetics
  geom_point(aes(color = var3, size = var4)) +     # 2. Geometry + Local aes
  scale_color_viridis_d() +                        # 3. Scales
  scale_size_continuous(range = c(2, 6)) +         # 4. More scales
  facet_wrap(~ var5) +                             # 5. Facets
  labs(title = "My Plot",                          # 6. Labels
       x = "X Label", y = "Y Label") +
  theme_minimal() +                                # 7. Theme
  theme(legend.position = "bottom",                # 8. Theme customization
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Key Takeaways


Grammar of Graphics provides a systematic framework for building visualizations
Layering is fundamental - data → aesthetics → geometries → scales → themes
Aesthetics map data to visual properties (inside aes())
Geoms are the building blocks - choose appropriately for your data type
Themes control appearance - use built-in or create custom ones
Colors matter - always consider colorblind accessibility
Scales control how data maps to aesthetics - customize breaks, limits, labels
Facets enable small multiples for comparing groups
Consistency is key - use global themes and organizational standards
Know ggplot2’s limitations and when to use alternatives

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
section: What We Covered Across All Modules
text:
What We Covered Across All Modules

Module 1: Foundations & Basic Geoms - Seven layers of Grammar of Graphics - Essential geoms: point, line, col, bar, histogram, boxplot, violin, smooth, density, jitter - Data preparation and handling missing data
Module 2: Aesthetics, Faceting & Themes - Global vs local aesthetics - facet_wrap() and facet_grid() - Built-in themes and ggthemes package
Module 3: Colors, Scales & Custom Themes - Color palettes and accessibility (viridis, ColorBrewer, paletteer) - Scale functions (manual, gradient, continuous, discrete) - Custom theme creation with element functions
Module 4: Advanced Topics & Best Practices - Complex visualizations and progressive builds - Exporting and reproducibility - Limitations and alternatives - Best practices and common pitfalls

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Resources for Further Learning
Books: - “ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis” by Hadley Wickham - “R Graphics Cookbook” by Winston Chang - “Fundamentals of Data Visualization” by Claus O. Wilke
Online Resources: - Official documentation: https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/ - R Graph Gallery: https://r-graph-gallery.com/ - ggplot2 extensions: https://exts.ggplot2.tidyverse.org/ - Tidyverse style guide: https://style.tidyverse.org/
Cheat Sheets: - RStudio ggplot2 cheat sheet - Data visualization with ggplot2 cheat sheet

text:

geom_point()       # Scatter plots

geom_ribbon()      # Confidence bands

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Quick Reference: Essential Scales


Code
scale_color_manual()      # Custom colors
scale_fill_viridis_d()    # Colorblind-friendly discrete
scale_x_continuous()      # Continuous x-axis
scale_y_log10()           # Log transformation
scale_color_brewer()      # ColorBrewer palettes

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Quick Reference: Theme Elements


Code
# Text elements
axis.title, axis.text, plot.title, plot.subtitle, 
plot.caption, legend.title, legend.text

# Line elements
axis.line, panel.grid.major, panel.grid.minor

# Rectangle elements
plot.background, panel.background, panel.border,
legend.background, legend.key

# Position
legend.position = "top" | "bottom" | "left" | "right" | "none" | c(x,y)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Bonus: Combining Plots with patchwork


Code
library(patchwork)

# Create individual plots
p1 <- ggplot(bp_data, aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) + geom_point()
p2 <- ggplot(bp_data, aes(x = BMI, y = Cholesterol)) + geom_point()
p3 <- ggplot(bp_data, aes(x = Region, y = SysBP_0m)) + geom_boxplot()
p4 <- ggplot(bp_data, aes(x = SysBP_Change)) + geom_histogram()

# Combine in various layouts
p1 + p2 + p3 + p4                    # Side by side
(p1 | p2) / (p3 | p4)                # Grid
p1 / (p2 | p3)                       # Complex layout



patchwork makes combining plots intuitive with +, |, and / operators

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text: Bonus: Example Combined Plot

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Module 2 Overview
Previously (Module 1): - Grammar of Graphics foundations - Seven layers - Basic geoms
This Module: - Aesthetic mappings deep dive - Faceting strategies - Built-in themes - ggthemes package

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Setup: Load Data


Code
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(readxl)
library(ggthemes)  # For additional themes

# Load and prepare data
bp_data <- read_excel("../../data/PublicHealth_BP_Dataset.xlsx") %>%
  mutate(
    SysBP_Change = SysBP_6m - SysBP_0m,
    AgeGroup = cut(Age, breaks = c(0, 30, 50, 65, 100),
                   labels = c("18-30", "31-50", "51-65", "65+")),
    Hypertension_Baseline = ifelse(SysBP_0m >= 140 | DiaBP_0m >= 90, 
                                   "Hypertensive", "Normal"),
    BMI_Category = cut(BMI, breaks = c(0, 18.5, 25, 30, 100),
                       labels = c("Underweight", "Normal", "Overweight", "Obese"))
  )

# Time series data
bp_time <- bp_data %>%
  select(PatientID, TreatmentGroup, SysBP_0m, SysBP_3m, SysBP_6m) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("SysBP"),
               names_to = "Time", values_to = "SysBP") %>%
  mutate(Months = as.numeric(gsub("SysBP_|m", "", Time)))

bp_summary <- bp_time %>%
  group_by(TreatmentGroup, Months) %>%
  summarise(Mean_SysBP = mean(SysBP, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Global vs Local Aesthetics


Global aesthetics: Defined in ggplot(), apply to all layers
Local aesthetics: Defined in geom_*(), apply to specific layer
Local aesthetics override global aesthetics
Use global for shared mappings, local for layer-specific mappings




Code
ggplot(data, aes(x = var1, y = var2)) +          # Global
  geom_point(aes(color = var3)) +                 # Local (adds color)
  geom_smooth()                                   # Uses global only

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Global Aesthetics Example




Code
# Global color applies to both layers
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m, 
           color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE)



Both geom_point() and geom_smooth() use the color mapping

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Local Aesthetics Override




Code
# Local aesthetic overrides global
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = TreatmentGroup), 
             size = 3, alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", 
              color = "black", linewidth = 1.5)



Points are colored by treatment, but smooth line is black

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Common Aesthetics: Color & Fill




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Region, y = SysBP_0m,
           fill = Region)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7)



color: Outlines of geoms (points, lines)
fill: Interior of geoms (bars, areas, polygons)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Common Aesthetics: Size




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
           size = BMI, color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6)



size: Point size or line width, mapped to continuous variable

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Common Aesthetics: Shape




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = Cholesterol,
           shape = Gender, 
           color = Gender)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7)



shape: Point shape (circles, squares, triangles, etc.)
Best for categorical variables with few levels (≤6)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Common Aesthetics: Alpha (Transparency)




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = BMI, y = SysBP_0m,
           alpha = Cholesterol)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, color = "darkred")



alpha: Transparency (0 = transparent, 1 = opaque)
Useful for showing density in overplotted data

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Multiple Aesthetics Combined




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
           color = TreatmentGroup,
           shape = Gender,
           size = BMI)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6)



Can combine multiple aesthetics, but be careful not to overwhelm!

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
section: Aesthetic Mapping: Inside vs Outside aes()
text:
Aesthetic Mapping: Inside vs Outside aes()




Code
# MAPPED to data (inside aes)
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
           color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_point(size = 3)

# FIXED value (outside aes)
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(color = "blue", size = 3)



Key rule: Inside aes() = mapped to data, Outside = fixed value

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Common Pitfall: Mapping Constants




Code
# WRONG - Don't map constants
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
           color = "blue")) +        # ❌
  geom_point()

# CORRECT - Set fixed values outside aes
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(color = "blue")         # ✓

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
facet_wrap(): Single Variable Faceting




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6, size = 2) +
  facet_wrap(~ TreatmentGroup) +
  theme_minimal()



Use for: Creating subplots for each level of one categorical variable

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
facet_wrap(): Multiple Columns




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = BMI, y = Cholesterol)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6, color = "darkred") +
  facet_wrap(~ Region, ncol = 2) +
  theme_minimal()



ncol parameter controls layout columns

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
facet_grid(): Two Variable Grid




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5, size = 1.5) +
  facet_grid(Gender ~ TreatmentGroup) +
  theme_minimal()



Use for: Creating a grid with rows and columns from two variables
Formula: rows ~ columns

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Free Scales in Facets




Code
# Create data with different ranges
smoking_bp <- bp_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(SmokingStatus)) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(SysBP_0m, DiaBP_0m),
               names_to = "BP_Type",
               values_to = "Value")

ggplot(smoking_bp, aes(x = SmokingStatus, y = Value)) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = "lightblue") +
  facet_wrap(~ BP_Type, scales = "free_y")



scales: “fixed” (default), “free”, “free_x”, “free_y”

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Facets with Multiple Geoms




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.4, size = 1.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", 
              color = "darkred", se = TRUE) +
  facet_wrap(~ TreatmentGroup) +
  theme_minimal()



Each facet gets all layers - points and smooth line

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Complex Faceting Example




Code
# Handle missing data
bp_complete <- bp_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(ExerciseFreq))

ggplot(bp_complete, 
       aes(x = AgeGroup, y = SysBP_Change,
           fill = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  facet_wrap(~ ExerciseFreq, ncol = 3) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = 
          element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Theme System Overview


Themes control non-data elements of plots
Affect: fonts, colors, backgrounds, grid lines, axes
ggplot2 includes 8 built-in complete themes
Each theme suited for different contexts
Can be customized further with theme() function



Basic usage: + theme_minimal()

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_gray() - Default Theme




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Region, y = SysBP_0m, 
           fill = Region)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_gray(base_size = 14)



Characteristics: Gray background, white grid lines
Best for: General exploratory analysis, default choice

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_bw() - Black and White




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Region, y = SysBP_0m, 
           fill = Region)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_bw(base_size = 14)



Characteristics: White background, gray grid lines, black border
Best for: Professional reports, publications, clean appearance

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_minimal() - Minimalist




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Region, y = SysBP_0m, 
           fill = Region)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14)



Characteristics: No background, minimal grid lines
Best for: Presentations, modern clean look, focus on data

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_classic() - Classic Look




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Region, y = SysBP_0m, 
           fill = Region)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_classic(base_size = 14)



Characteristics: White background, no grid, axis lines only
Best for: Scientific publications, traditional journals, base R style

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_light() & theme_dark()




Code
# Light theme
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(color = "steelblue") +
  theme_light(base_size = 14)










Code
# Dark theme
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(color = "cyan") +
  theme_dark(base_size = 14)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_void() - Completely Blank




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Longitude, y = Latitude,
           color = Region)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_void()



Characteristics: No axes, no grid, no background
Best for: Maps, specialized graphics, pure data visualization

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text: Theme Comparison

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
ggthemes Package Overview


Additional themes inspired by famous publications and software
Professional, publication-ready aesthetics
Color palettes matching each theme
Includes themes from: Economist, FiveThirtyEight, Tufte, WSJ, Stata, Excel, and more




Code
library(ggthemes)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_economist() - The Economist Style




Code
ggplot(bp_summary, 
       aes(x = Months, y = Mean_SysBP,
           color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.5) +
  scale_color_economist() +
  theme_economist()



Style: Blue background, distinctive typography
Use for: Business reports, policy documents, professional presentations

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_fivethirtyeight()




Code
# Region summary
region_summary <- bp_data %>%
  group_by(Region) %>%
  summarise(Mean_SysBP = mean(SysBP_0m),
            N = n())

ggplot(region_summary, 
       aes(x = reorder(Region, -Mean_SysBP), 
           y = Mean_SysBP, fill = Region)) +
  geom_col() +
  theme_fivethirtyeight()



Style: Gray background, bold colors, large text
Use for: Data journalism, blog posts, engaging visualizations

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_tufte() - Minimalism




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  theme_tufte(base_size = 14)



Style: Minimal ink, maximum data-ink ratio
Use for: Scientific papers, when “less is more”

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_few() - Stephen Few’s Style




Code
ggplot(bp_data %>% filter(!is.na(BMI_Category)), 
       aes(x = BMI_Category, y = Cholesterol,
           fill = BMI_Category)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  scale_fill_few() +
  theme_few()



Style: Clean, professional, colorblind-friendly
Use for: Business intelligence, dashboards

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
When to Use Which Theme?








Theme
Best For
Avoid When




theme_gray()
Exploratory analysis
Publications


theme_bw()
Reports, professional docs
Presentations


theme_minimal()
Presentations, modern look
Traditional journals


theme_classic()
Scientific publications
Web/digital


theme_economist()
Business reports
Academic papers


theme_fivethirtyeight()
Data journalism
Formal reports


theme_tufte()
Minimalist publications
Need context/grid


theme_few()
Dashboards, BI
Decorative needs

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Module 2 Summary
What we covered:


Global vs local aesthetics
Common aesthetic mappings (color, fill, size, shape, alpha)
Inside vs outside aes()
facet_wrap() and facet_grid()
Free scales in facets
Built-in themes (gray, bw, minimal, classic, light, dark, void)
ggthemes package (economist, fivethirtyeight, tufte, few)



Next in Module 3: - Color palettes and accessibility - Scale functions deep dive - Custom theme creation with theme()
