title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text:
What is Categorical Data?


Definition:
Data that represents categories, groups, or labels

Finite set of discrete values
No inherent numerical order (usually)
Qualitative rather than quantitative


Examples in Our Dataset:

Treatment Group (Control, Intervention)
Gender (Male, Female, Other)
Region (North, South, East, West)
Smoking Status
Alcohol Use
Exercise Frequency
Chronic Disease

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text:
Analytical Goals for Categorical Data

What questions can we answer?


🟢 Ranking - Which category is most/least common?
🟡 Distribution - How are observations spread across categories?
🔴 Part of Whole - What proportion does each category represent?


Charts we’ll learn:

Bar Chart (Vertical & Horizontal)
Pie Chart
Donut Chart
Stacked Bar Chart

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text:
Setup: Load Libraries and Data


Code
# Load required libraries
library(ggplot2)    # For creating plots
library(dplyr)      # For data manipulation

# Load the dataset
data <- readxl::read_excel("PublicHealth_BP_Dataset.xlsx")

# Handle missing data: filter to complete cases for ExerciseFreq
data_clean <- data %>%
  filter(!is.na(ExerciseFreq))  # Remove rows with missing exercise frequency

# Preview the data
head(data_clean %>% 
  select(PatientID, TreatmentGroup, Gender, Region, SmokingStatus))

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text:
Setup: Load Libraries and Data


# A tibble: 10 × 5
   PatientID TreatmentGroup Gender Region SmokingStatus 
       <dbl> <chr>          <chr>  <chr>  <chr>         
 1         1 Control        Female South  Non-smoker    
 2         2 Control        Male   South  Former smoker 
 3         3 Control        Male   West   Former smoker 
 4         4 Intervention   Female West   Current smoker
 5         5 Intervention   Male   West   Current smoker
 6         6 Intervention   Male   North  Former smoker 
 7         7 Control        Male   East   Current smoker
 8         8 Intervention   Male   North  Former smoker 
 9         9 Intervention   Female East   Former smoker 
10        10 Control        Male   North  Non-smoker

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text:
Bar Chart (Vertical) - Code
🟢 Goal: Ranking / Distribution


Code
# Create vertical bar chart showing patient count by region
ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = Region)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "steelblue", alpha = 0.8) +  # Add bars with color
  labs(title = "Patient Distribution by Region",
       x = "Region", y = "Count of Patients") +  # Add labels
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +  # Apply serif font theme
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
        axis.text = element_text(size = 10))




Line 1-2: Set up plot with Region on x-axis, counts automatically calculated
Line 3: Add bar geometry with steel blue fill and transparency
Line 4-5: Add descriptive title and axis labels
Line 6: Apply minimal theme with serif font for professional look
Line 7-9: Customize title and axis text sizes

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text: Bar Chart (Vertical) - Plot

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text:
Horizontal Bar Chart - Code
🟢 Goal: Ranking (ordered by value)


Code
# Create horizontal bar chart with categories ordered by count
smoking_counts <- data_clean %>%
  count(SmokingStatus) %>%  # Count observations per smoking status
  arrange(n)  # Arrange from smallest to largest

ggplot(smoking_counts, aes(x = n, y = reorder(SmokingStatus, n))) +
  geom_col(fill = "darkgreen", alpha = 0.7) +  # Use geom_col for pre-counted data
  labs(title = "Patient Count by Smoking Status (Ranked)",
       x = "Number of Patients", y = "Smoking Status") +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
        axis.text = element_text(size = 10))




Lines 1-3: Count patients per smoking status category
Line 4: Sort ascending so chart displays with largest at top
Line 5: reorder() arranges y-axis by count value
Line 6: geom_col() used when you have pre-calculated counts

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text: Horizontal Bar Chart - Plot

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text:
How to Read Bar Charts
Using the previous plot as example:

OBSERVATION: - Non-smokers: ~115 patients (largest group) - Former smokers: ~40 patients (middle) - Current smokers: ~35 patients (smallest) - Clear hierarchy in the data
INTERPRETATION: - Majority of study participants are non-smokers (>70%) - Combined smokers (current + former) represent ~30% - Good representation across smoking statuses for analysis
IMPLICATIONS: - Sufficient sample in each group for subgroup analysis - Non-smoker group may dominate overall results - Consider stratified analysis by smoking status
ACTIONS: - Use smoking status as a key stratification variable - Ensure statistical power for smoker subgroups - Watch for interaction effects with treatment

:::

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text:
Pie Chart - Code
🔴 Goal: Part of a Whole


Code
# Calculate percentages for treatment groups
treatment_summary <- data_clean %>%
  count(TreatmentGroup) %>%
  mutate(percentage = n / sum(n) * 100)  # Calculate percentages

# Create pie chart using coord_polar transformation
ggplot(treatment_summary, aes(x = "", y = n, fill = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", width = 1, color = "white") +  # Create stacked bar
  coord_polar("y", start = 0) +  # Transform to polar coordinates (pie)
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Control" = "#E74C3C", "Intervention" = "#3498DB")) +
  geom_text(aes(label = paste0(round(percentage, 1), "%")), 
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5),
            family = "serif", size = 5) +  # Add percentage labels
  labs(title = "Treatment Group Distribution",
       fill = "Group") +
  theme_void(base_family = "serif") +  # Remove axes for clean pie
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"))



⚠️ Warning: Use pie charts only for 2-5 categories!

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text: Pie Chart - Plot

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text:
Donut Chart - Code
🔴 Goal: Part of a Whole (modern alternative to pie)


Code
# Calculate percentages for gender distribution
gender_summary <- data_clean %>%
  count(Gender) %>%
  mutate(percentage = n / sum(n) * 100)

# Create donut chart (pie with hole in center)
ggplot(gender_summary, aes(x = 2, y = n, fill = Gender)) +  # x=2 creates the hole
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", width = 1, color = "white") +
  coord_polar("y", start = 0) +
  xlim(0.5, 2.5) +  # Creates the "donut hole" effect
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") +  # Use professional color palette
  geom_text(aes(label = paste0(Gender, "\n", round(percentage, 1), "%")),
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5),
            family = "serif", size = 4) +
  labs(title = "Patient Gender Distribution") +
  theme_void(base_family = "serif") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        legend.position = "right")

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text: Donut Chart - Plot

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text:
Stacked Bar Chart - Code
🔴 Goal: Part of a Whole + Comparison across groups


Code
# Create stacked bar showing smoking status by region
ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = Region, fill = SmokingStatus)) +
  geom_bar(position = "stack", alpha = 0.8) +  # Stack bars on top of each other
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Current smoker" = "#E74C3C",
                                "Former smoker" = "#F39C12",
                                "Non-smoker" = "#27AE60"),
                    name = "Smoking Status") +  # Custom colors
  labs(title = "Smoking Status Distribution by Region",
       x = "Region",
       y = "Number of Patients") +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
        axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
        legend.position = "right")



Stacked bars show both total count AND composition within each category

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text: Stacked Bar Chart - Plot

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text:
Categorical Plots - Summary









Chart Type
Goal
When to Use
Code Complexity




Vertical Bar
🟢 Ranking / 🟡 Distribution
Few categories (3-7)
Simple (3-5 lines)


Horizontal Bar
🟢 Ranking (ordered)
Long category names, many categories
Simple (5-7 lines)


Pie Chart
🔴 Part of Whole
Only 2-5 categories!
Medium (8-10 lines)


Donut Chart
🔴 Part of Whole
Modern alternative to pie
Medium (8-10 lines)


Stacked Bar
🔴 Part + 🟢 Comparison
Composition across groups
Medium (8-12 lines)

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text:
Key Takeaways


Remember:

Bar charts are versatile - use for most categorical data
Order matters - arrange by value for rankings
Avoid pie charts beyond 5 categories
Color strategically - use consistent, meaningful colors
Handle missing data - filter or document approach

Common Mistakes:

Using 3D effects (distorts perception)
Too many categories (>10)
Poor color choices (similar shades)
Missing labels or titles
Inconsistent formatting

text:

Variable: AlcoholUse (Yes/No)
Sort by count
Use appropriate colors
Add percentage labels

title: Categorical Plots - BASIC
text:
Next Steps
You’ve mastered Categorical - Basic!
Next: Continuous Plots - Basic
Learn to visualize numeric data with: - Histograms - Density plots - Scatter plots - Box plots

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
section: What is Category vs. Continuous Data?
text:
What is Category vs. Continuous Data?


Definition:
Combining categorical variables (groups) with continuous variables (numeric measurements)

Compare numeric values across categories
Show distributions within groups
Analyze differences between segments


Examples in Our Dataset:

BMI by Gender
Blood Pressure by Treatment Group
Cholesterol by Region
Age by Smoking Status
Blood Sugar by Exercise Frequency

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
text:
Analytical Goals

What questions can we answer?


🟡 Distribution - How do values spread within each category?
🟢 Ranking - Which group has highest/lowest values?
🔴 Part of Whole - How do groups contribute to total?
⚫ Correlation - Do patterns differ across groups?


Charts we’ll learn:

Box Plot
Grouped Bar Chart
Stacked Bar Chart

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
text:
Setup: Load Data


Code
# Load required libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

# Load the dataset
data <- readxl::read_excel("../../data/PublicHealth_BP_Dataset.xlsx")

# Handle missing data for complete case analysis
data_clean <- data %>%
  filter(!is.na(ExerciseFreq), !is.na(ChronicDisease))  # Remove rows with missing values

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
text:
Data Preview


# A tibble: 2 × 5
  TreatmentGroup Count Mean_Age Mean_BMI Mean_SysBP
  <chr>          <int>    <dbl>    <dbl>      <dbl>
1 Control           98     47.5     24.5       136.
2 Intervention      98     52.3     25.9       134.

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
text:
Box Plot - Code
🟡 Goal: Compare distributions across groups


Code
# Create box plot comparing BMI by Treatment Group
ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = TreatmentGroup, y = BMI, fill = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7, outlier.color = "red", outlier.size = 3) +  # Add box plots
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Control" = "#E74C3C", 
                                "Intervention" = "#3498DB"),
                    name = "Treatment Group") +  # Custom colors
  labs(title = "BMI Distribution by Treatment Group",
       x = "Treatment Group", y = "Body Mass Index (BMI)") +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
        legend.position = "none")  # Hide legend (redundant with x-axis)



Box plot shows: minimum, Q1 (25%), median (50%), Q3 (75%), maximum, and outliers

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
text: Box Plot - Plot

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
text:
How to Read Box Plots
Using the previous plot:

Reading the 5-Number Summary: - Bottom whisker: Minimum (~12-15) - Bottom of box (Q1): 25th percentile (~22) - Line in box (Median): 50th percentile (~25) - Top of box (Q3): 75th percentile (~28) - Top whisker: Maximum (~35) - Red dots: Outliers beyond 1.5 × IQR
OBSERVATION: - Both groups have similar median BMI (~25) - Both groups show symmetric distributions - Control group: slightly wider box (more variation) - Few outliers in both groups - Boxes largely overlap
INTERPRETATION: - No substantial difference in BMI between treatment groups at baseline - Random assignment appears successful (balanced groups) - Similar BMI variability in both groups - Treatment groups comparable on this key health metric
IMPLICATIONS: - BMI unlikely to confound treatment effect - Groups well-balanced for analysis - Any post-treatment BMI differences likely due to treatment, not baseline
ACTIONS: - Proceed with treatment comparison without BMI adjustment - May still include BMI as covariate for precision - Monitor for BMI changes during study

:::

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
section: Box Plot with Multiple Categories - Code
text:
Box Plot with Multiple Categories - Code
🟡 Goal: Compare distributions across many groups


Code
# Compare Cholesterol across all regions
ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = reorder(Region, Cholesterol, FUN = median), 
                       y = Cholesterol, fill = Region)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7, outlier.shape = 16, outlier.size = 2) +  # Box plots
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2", name = "Region") +  # Use color palette
  labs(title = "Cholesterol Levels by Region (Ordered by Median)",
       x = "Region", 
       y = "Cholesterol (mg/dL)") +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
        axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
        legend.position = "none")  # X-axis provides category names



reorder() sorts regions by median cholesterol for easier comparison

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
text: Box Plot - Multiple Groups Plot

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
text:
Grouped Bar Chart - Code
🟢 Goal: Compare means across categories and groups


Code
# Calculate mean systolic BP by Region and Treatment Group
bp_summary <- data_clean %>%
  group_by(Region, TreatmentGroup) %>%
  summarise(Mean_SysBP = mean(SysBP_0m, na.rm = TRUE),
            .groups = "drop")  # Calculate group means

# Create grouped bar chart
ggplot(bp_summary, aes(x = Region, y = Mean_SysBP, fill = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge", alpha = 0.8) +  # Bars side-by-side
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Control" = "#E74C3C", 
                                "Intervention" = "#3498DB"),
                    name = "Treatment Group") +
  labs(title = "Mean Baseline Systolic BP by Region and Treatment Group",
       x = "Region", 
       y = "Mean Systolic BP (mmHg)") +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 15, face = "bold"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
        legend.position = "right")

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
text: Grouped Bar Chart - Plot

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
text:
Stacked Bar Chart - Code
🔴 Goal: Part of Whole + Comparison


Code
# Count patients by Region and Gender
region_gender <- data_clean %>%
  count(Region, Gender) %>%
  filter(Gender != "Other")  # Remove small category for clarity

# Create stacked bar chart
ggplot(region_gender, aes(x = Region, y = n, fill = Gender)) +
  geom_col(position = "stack", alpha = 0.8) +  # Stack bars
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Female" = "#E91E63", 
                                "Male" = "#2196F3"),
                    name = "Gender") +
  geom_text(aes(label = n), position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5),
            color = "white", family = "serif", fontface = "bold", size = 4) +  # Add counts
  labs(title = "Patient Count by Region and Gender",
       x = "Region", 
       y = "Number of Patients") +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
        legend.position = "right")

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
text: Stacked Bar Chart - Plot

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
text:
Category vs. Continuous - Summary









Chart Type
Goal
When to Use
Code Complexity




Box Plot
🟡 Distribution
Compare distributions across 2-6 groups
Simple (4-6 lines)


Box Plot (Multiple)
🟡 Distribution
Compare many groups, show ranking
Medium (6-8 lines)


Grouped Bar
🟢 Ranking/Comparison
Compare means across categories
Medium (8-12 lines)


Stacked Bar
🔴 Part of Whole
Show composition and totals
Medium (8-12 lines)

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
text:
Understanding Box Plots


The Box: - Bottom edge: Q1 (25th percentile) - Middle line: Median (50th percentile) - Top edge: Q3 (75th percentile) - Box height: IQR (Q3 - Q1)
The Whiskers: - Extend to 1.5 × IQR - Show data range (excluding outliers)

Outliers: - Points beyond whiskers - May indicate: - Data entry errors - Natural extreme values - Different population
Comparing Boxes: - Non-overlapping: likely different - Overlapping: may not be different - Check median positions - Compare IQR widths

title: Category vs. Continuous - BASIC
text:
Key Takeaways


Remember:

Box plots show distribution - not just means
Order categories - by median or logically
Grouped vs. Stacked bars - different purposes
Always show units - in axis labels
Handle outliers thoughtfully - investigate but don’t automatically remove

Common Mistakes:

Too many categories in one plot (>8)
Not ordering categories logically
Confusing grouped and stacked bars
Ignoring outliers without investigation
Comparing means without showing variation

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Enhanced Continuous Visualizations

Building on Basic Skills:
Moving beyond simple histograms and scatter plots to sophisticated statistical visualizations.
New Techniques: - Violin plots (distribution + density) - Ridgeline plots (comparing many distributions) - 2D density plots (large scatter data) - Hexbin plots (overplotting solution) - Scatter with regression (trend lines)
New Packages: - ggridges for ridgeline plots - hexbin for hexagonal binning - Statistical layers in ggplot2

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Setup


Code
# Load required libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(ggridges)    # For ridgeline plots
library(hexbin)      # For hexbin plots

# Load dataset
data <- readxl::read_excel("../../data/PublicHealth_BP_Dataset.xlsx")

# Clean data: complete cases for analysis
data_clean <- data %>%
  filter(!is.na(BMI), !is.na(Cholesterol), !is.na(ExerciseFreq))

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Data Preview


# A tibble: 4 × 5
  Region Count Mean_BMI SD_BMI Mean_Chol
  <chr>  <int>    <dbl>  <dbl>     <dbl>
1 East      40     26.2   4.76      236.
2 North     65     24.8   4.36      230.
3 South     47     24.6   4.65      220.
4 West      46     25.5   5.11      228.

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Violin Plot - Code
🟡 Goal: Show full distribution shape by group


Code
# Create violin plot comparing BMI across regions
ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = Region, y = BMI, fill = Region)) +
  geom_violin(alpha = 0.7, trim = FALSE) +  # Create violin shapes
  geom_boxplot(width = 0.15, alpha = 0.5, outlier.shape = NA) +  # Add boxplot inside
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2", name = "Region") +  # Color palette
  labs(title = "BMI Distribution by Region (Violin Plot)",
       x = "Region", y = "Body Mass Index (BMI)") +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
        legend.position = "none")  # X-axis labels regions



Violin plot = rotated density plot on each side. Wider = more data at that value

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text: Violin Plot - Plot

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text:
How to Read Violin Plots
Using the previous plot:

OBSERVATION: - All regions show symmetric, roughly normal distributions - Widest parts (bulges) around BMI 25 for most regions - South region: slightly wider violin (more variation) - Boxplots inside show median and quartiles - No extreme outliers visible
INTERPRETATION: - BMI distributions similar across all regions - Most patients cluster around BMI 25 (normal/overweight boundary) - South region has more variability in BMI - No regional bias in BMI recruitment - Distributions roughly normal (good for parametric tests)
IMPLICATIONS: - Regional effects on outcomes unlikely due to BMI differences - Can pool regions for BMI-related analyses - South’s higher variability may need investigation - Sample representative across regions for BMI
ACTIONS: - Proceed with region-pooled analyses for BMI - Consider South region variability in sensitivity analyses - Use BMI as continuous covariate (not categorized by region)

:::

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Ridgeline Plot - Code
🟡 Goal: Compare many distributions elegantly


Code
# Create ridgeline plot of Cholesterol by Exercise Frequency
# (overlapping density plots, like mountain ridges)
ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = Cholesterol, y = ExerciseFreq, fill = ExerciseFreq)) +
  geom_density_ridges(alpha = 0.7, scale = 1.2) +  # Create overlapping densities
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2", name = "Exercise Frequency") +
  labs(title = "Cholesterol Distribution by Exercise Frequency",
       x = "Cholesterol (mg/dL)", 
       y = "Exercise Frequency") +
  theme_ridges(font_family = "serif") +  # Special theme for ridgeline plots
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
        legend.position = "none")



Ridgeline plots are perfect when comparing 3+ groups. Scale parameter controls overlap

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text: Ridgeline Plot - Plot

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text:
2D Density Plot - Code
⚫ Goal: Show correlation patterns with density contours


Code
# Create 2D density contour plot for Age vs. Cholesterol
ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = Age, y = Cholesterol)) +
  geom_density_2d_filled(alpha = 0.8, contour_var = "ndensity") +  # Filled contours
  geom_point(size = 0.5, alpha = 0.3, color = "white") +  # Add semi-transparent points
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "plasma", name = "Density") +  # Color scale
  labs(title = "2D Density: Age vs. Cholesterol Relationship",
       x = "Age (years)", 
       y = "Cholesterol (mg/dL)") +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12))



2D density shows where most data points cluster. Darker = higher concentration

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text: 2D Density Plot - Plot

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Hexbin Plot - Code
⚫ Goal: Handle overplotting in large scatter plots


Code
# Create hexbin plot for BMI vs. Blood Sugar (handles overlapping points)
ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = BMI, y = BloodSugar)) +
  geom_hex(bins = 30) +  # Create hexagonal bins
  scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "inferno", name = "Count") +  # Color by count
  labs(title = "BMI vs. Blood Sugar (Hexbin Plot)",
       x = "Body Mass Index (BMI)", 
       y = "Blood Sugar (mg/dL)") +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12))



Hexbin divides plot into hexagons and counts points in each. Better than overlapping points

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text: Hexbin Plot - Plot

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Scatter with Regression Line - Code
⚫ Goal: Show correlation with statistical trend


Code
# Scatter plot with linear regression line and confidence interval
ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5, color = "steelblue", size = 2.5) +  # Add points
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE, color = "#E74C3C", 
              fill = "#E74C3C", alpha = 0.2, size = 1.2) +  # Add regression line + CI
  # Calculate and display correlation
  annotate("text", x = 25, y = 160, 
           label = paste("r =", round(cor(data_clean$Age, data_clean$SysBP_0m), 3)),
           family = "serif", size = 5, fontface = "bold") +
  labs(title = "Age vs. Baseline Systolic BP with Regression Line",
       subtitle = "Linear trend with 95% confidence interval",
       x = "Age (years)", 
       y = "Systolic Blood Pressure (mmHg)") +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
        plot.subtitle = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 12),
        axis.title = element_text(size = 12))

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text: Scatter with Regression - Plot

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Reading Advanced Continuous Plots
Using the regression plot:

OBSERVATION: - Weak positive correlation (r ≈ 0.2-0.3) - Regression line slopes upward slightly - Wide confidence interval (uncertainty in relationship) - Substantial scatter around the line - Age range: 18-79 years, BP range: 100-165 mmHg
INTERPRETATION: - Age explains only small portion of BP variation (~4-9% via r²) - Systolic BP tends to increase slightly with age (expected) - Many other factors influence BP beyond age - Relationship is linear but weak - Individual variation is large
IMPLICATIONS: - Age alone is poor predictor of BP - Need multivariate models (BMI, smoking, etc.) - Age adjustment important but not sufficient - Biological relationship exists but is noisy - Clinical: Don’t assume high BP from age alone
CRITICAL REMINDERS: - Correlation ≠ Causation (age doesn’t “cause” high BP directly) - r < 0.3 = weak, 0.3-0.7 = moderate, >0.7 = strong - Always check confidence interval width - Look for non-linear patterns

:::

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Violin vs. Box Plot


Box Plot Shows: - 5-number summary - Median (50th percentile) - Quartiles (25th, 75th) - Outliers - Missing: Distribution shape
Use When: - Quick comparison needed - Focus on median/quartiles - Outliers are important

Violin Plot Shows: - Full distribution shape - Density at each value - Can see bimodal patterns - Shows skewness clearly - Missing: Exact quantiles
Use When: - Shape matters - Want to see multiple peaks - Comparing distributions - Publication quality needed

title: Continuous Plots - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Key Takeaways


Remember:

Violin plots show what box plots hide (distribution shape)
Ridgeline plots scale well to 5-10 groups
2D density reveals clustering patterns
Hexbin solves overplotting automatically
Always show confidence intervals on regression lines

Common Mistakes: - Using violin plots with < 20 observations per group - Too many groups in ridgeline (>10 gets cluttered) - Forgetting to show confidence intervals - Interpreting weak correlations as strong relationships - Not checking for non-linear patterns
Pro Tips: - Add boxplot inside violin for best of both worlds - scale parameter in ridgeline controls overlap - Use alpha transparency to show density overlaps - Always report correlation coefficient with regression

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text:
What We’ll Learn - Intermediate


Beyond Simple Line Charts:

Smoothed trends (LOESS, moving average)
Area charts with confidence bands
Multi-series comparison plots
Annotations and event markers
Seasonal patterns
Change highlighting


Analytical Goals:

🔵 Evolution - How things change over time
🟡 Distribution - Spread at different times
🟢 Ranking - Compare multiple series
⚫ Correlation - Relationship between series

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Setup Code


Code
# Load required packages
library(readxl)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyr)
library(zoo)      # For moving averages
library(lubridate) # For date handling

# Load dataset and create time series data
health_data <- read_excel("../../data/PublicHealth_BP_Dataset.xlsx")

# Aggregate by time point
time_data <- health_data %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(SysBP_0m, SysBP_3m, SysBP_6m),
               names_to = "TimePoint",
               values_to = "SysBP") %>%
  mutate(Month = case_when(
    TimePoint == "SysBP_0m" ~ 0,
    TimePoint == "SysBP_3m" ~ 3,
    TimePoint == "SysBP_6m" ~ 6
  ))

# Create theme
theme_custom <- function() {
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    text = element_text(family = "serif", size = 12),
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 11, hjust = 0.5),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 11),
    legend.position = "bottom"
  )
}

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Smoothed Trend with LOESS - Code

Purpose: Show underlying trend while reducing noise
Goal: 🔵 Evolution


Code
# Calculate mean BP by treatment group over time
trend_data <- time_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(TreatmentGroup), !is.na(SysBP)) %>%
  group_by(TreatmentGroup, Month) %>%
  summarise(
    mean_bp = mean(SysBP, na.rm = TRUE),
    se_bp = sd(SysBP, na.rm = TRUE) / sqrt(n()),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Create smoothed trend plot
ggplot(trend_data, aes(x = Month, y = mean_bp, 
                      color = TreatmentGroup, fill = TreatmentGroup)) +
  # Raw data points
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.6) +
  # Smoothed trend line
  geom_smooth(method = "loess",     # Locally weighted smoothing
              span = 0.75,          # Smoothness (larger = smoother)
              alpha = 0.2) +        # Confidence band transparency
  labs(title = "Blood Pressure Trends by Treatment Group",
       subtitle = "Smoothed LOESS curves with 95% confidence bands",
       x = "Time (months)",
       y = "Mean Systolic BP (mmHg)",
       color = "Treatment",
       fill = "Treatment") +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1") +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set1") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(0, 6, 12)) +
  theme_custom()

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text: Smoothed Trend with LOESS - Output

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Interpreting Smoothed Trends


LOESS Smoothing:

Local regression at each point
Reduces random fluctuations
Reveals underlying patterns
Confidence bands show uncertainty

Span parameter:

span = 0.3 - Very wiggly (follows data closely)
span = 0.75 - Moderate smoothing (default)
span = 1.5 - Very smooth (may miss details)


Our Findings:

All groups start similar at Month 0
Treatment A & B effective

Clear downward trend
BP drops ~15-20 mmHg

Control group stable

No significant change
As expected

Confidence bands widen over time

Less certainty in estimates
Possible dropout effects

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
section: Area Chart with Confidence Bands - Code
text:
Area Chart with Confidence Bands - Code

Purpose: Emphasize magnitude and uncertainty over time
Goal: 🔵 Evolution + 🟡 Distribution


Code
# Calculate confidence intervals manually
trend_ci <- trend_data %>%
  mutate(
    lower = mean_bp - 1.96 * se_bp,  # 95% CI
    upper = mean_bp + 1.96 * se_bp
  )

# Create area chart with confidence band
ggplot(trend_ci, aes(x = Month, y = mean_bp, 
                    color = TreatmentGroup, fill = TreatmentGroup)) +
  # Confidence band as ribbon
  geom_ribbon(aes(ymin = lower, ymax = upper), 
              alpha = 0.3, color = NA) +
  # Mean line
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +
  # Points at measurement times
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  labs(title = "Blood Pressure Changes with 95% Confidence Intervals",
       subtitle = "Shaded areas show uncertainty in estimates",
       x = "Time (months)",
       y = "Mean Systolic BP (mmHg)",
       color = "Treatment",
       fill = "Treatment") +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2") +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Dark2") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(0, 6, 12)) +
  theme_custom()

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
section: Area Chart with Confidence Bands - Output
text: Area Chart with Confidence Bands - Output

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Interpreting Area Charts

Key Observations:


Non-overlapping bands = Statistically different

Treatment A vs Control clearly different at 6 & 12 months

Overlapping bands = May not be different

Treatment A vs B overlap at all time points
Suggests similar effectiveness

Band width shows precision

Narrower = more precise estimate
Wider = more uncertainty

Trend direction immediately visible

Downward = improvement
Flat = no change
Upward = worsening

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Annotated Time Series - Code

Purpose: Highlight important events and changes
Goal: 🔵 Evolution + context


Code
# Prepare data for one treatment group
treatment_a_data <- trend_ci %>% filter(TreatmentGroup == "Treatment A")

# Create annotated plot
ggplot(treatment_a_data, aes(x = Month, y = mean_bp)) +
  # Area under curve
  geom_area(fill = "#4DBBD5", alpha = 0.3) +
  # Line and points
  geom_line(color = "#4DBBD5", linewidth = 1.5) +
  geom_point(size = 4, color = "#4DBBD5") +
  # Annotate starting point
  annotate("text", x = 0, y = 142, 
           label = "Baseline\n140 mmHg", 
           hjust = 0.5, vjust = -0.5, size = 4, fontface = "bold") +
  # Annotate 6-month check
  annotate("segment", x = 6, y = 125, xend = 6, yend = 130,
           arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.3, "cm")), 
           color = "red", linewidth = 1) +
  annotate("text", x = 6, y = 123, 
           label = "First improvement\n-15 mmHg", 
           hjust = 0.5, size = 3.5, color = "red") +
  # Annotate final result
  annotate("text", x = 12, y = 118, 
           label = "Final: 120 mmHg\n✓ Target achieved", 
           hjust = 0.5, vjust = 1.2, size = 4, fontface = "bold", color = "darkgreen") +
  # Add horizontal reference line for target BP
  geom_hline(yintercept = 120, linetype = "dashed", 
             color = "darkgreen", linewidth = 0.8) +
  labs(title = "Treatment A: Blood Pressure Reduction Over 12 Months",
       subtitle = "Green line shows target BP of 120 mmHg",
       x = "Time (months)",
       y = "Mean Systolic BP (mmHg)") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(0, 6, 12)) +
  ylim(110, 145) +
  theme_custom()

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text: Annotated Time Series - Output

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Effective Annotations

When to Annotate:


Key milestones - Important time points
Threshold crossings - When target is reached
Notable events - Interventions, policy changes
Unexpected changes - Spikes or drops
Comparisons - Differences from baseline

Best Practices:

Don’t over-annotate - 2-4 annotations max
Use arrows for clarity
Color-code meaningfully (red = bad, green = good)
Keep text brief - Key numbers + interpretation
Position carefully - Avoid overlapping

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Small Multiples - Code

Purpose: Compare many series side-by-side
Goal: 🔵 Evolution + 🟢 Ranking


Code
# Create small multiples by region
region_trends <- time_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(Region), !is.na(SysBP)) %>%
  group_by(Region, Month) %>%
  summarise(
    mean_bp = mean(SysBP, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Small multiples plot
ggplot(region_trends, aes(x = Month, y = mean_bp)) +
  geom_line(color = "#3C5488", linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_point(size = 3, color = "#3C5488") +
  geom_area(fill = "#3C5488", alpha = 0.2) +
  facet_wrap(~ Region, ncol = 2) +  # Split by region
  labs(title = "Blood Pressure Trends Across Regions",
       subtitle = "Small multiples enable direct comparison",
       x = "Time (months)",
       y = "Mean Systolic BP (mmHg)") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(0, 6, 12)) +
  theme_custom() +
  theme(
    strip.background = element_rect(fill = "gray90", color = "black"),
    strip.text = element_text(face = "bold", size = 11),
    panel.spacing = unit(1.5, "lines")  # Space between panels
  )

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text: Small Multiples - Output

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Interpreting Small Multiples

Power of Small Multiples:


Same scale enables direct comparison

Each region shows similar range

Pattern differences are immediately visible

West shows gradual increase
North shows decrease
East and South relatively stable

Easy to spot outliers or anomalies

West’s upward trend is unusual

Reduces cognitive load vs. overlapping lines

Each series has its own space
No color confusion


Insight: Regional trends vary - need to investigate West region

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Percent Change Plot - Code

Purpose: Show relative changes from baseline
Goal: 🔵 Evolution + comparison


Code
# Calculate percent change from baseline
pct_change_data <- time_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(TreatmentGroup), !is.na(SysBP)) %>%
  group_by(TreatmentGroup, Month) %>%
  summarise(mean_bp = mean(SysBP, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop") %>%
  group_by(TreatmentGroup) %>%
  mutate(
    baseline = first(mean_bp),           # Get baseline value
    pct_change = 100 * (mean_bp - baseline) / baseline  # % change
  )

# Create percent change plot
ggplot(pct_change_data, aes(x = Month, y = pct_change, 
                           color = TreatmentGroup, group = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray50") +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.3) +
  geom_point(size = 3.5) +
  labs(title = "Percent Change in Blood Pressure from Baseline",
       subtitle = "Negative values indicate improvement",
       x = "Time (months)",
       y = "Change from Baseline (%)",
       color = "Treatment") +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(0, 6, 12)) +
  theme_custom()

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text: Percent Change Plot - Output

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Interpreting Percent Change

Why Use Percent Change?


Normalizes different baselines

Groups with different starting points comparable

Shows relative effect size

Treatment A: ~15% reduction
Treatment B: ~12% reduction
Control: ~0% change

Makes communication easier

“15% reduction” more intuitive than “20 mmHg decrease”

Useful for different scales

Can compare BP, cholesterol, weight, etc. on same plot


Limitation: Can mislead if baseline values are very small

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Slope Graph - Code

Purpose: Highlight individual changes between two time points
Goal: 🔵 Evolution + individual patterns


Code
# Prepare data: baseline vs 12-month by treatment
slope_data <- health_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(TreatmentGroup), !is.na(SysBP_0m), !is.na(SysBP_6m)) %>%
  select(PatientID, TreatmentGroup, SysBP_0m, SysBP_6m) %>%
  group_by(TreatmentGroup) %>%
  slice_sample(n = 15) %>%  # Sample 15 patients per group
  ungroup() %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(SysBP_0m, SysBP_6m),
               names_to = "Time",
               values_to = "SysBP") %>%
  mutate(Time = ifelse(Time == "SysBP_0m", "Baseline", "6 Months"))

# Create slope graph
ggplot(slope_data, aes(x = Time, y = SysBP, group = PatientID,
                      color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_line(alpha = 0.6, linewidth = 0.8) +
  geom_point(size = 2.5, alpha = 0.8) +
  facet_wrap(~ TreatmentGroup, ncol = 3) +
  labs(title = "Individual Patient Blood Pressure Changes",
       subtitle = "Each line represents one patient (n=15 per group)",
       x = "",
       y = "Systolic BP (mmHg)") +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2") +
  theme_custom() +
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        strip.background = element_rect(fill = "gray90"),
        strip.text = element_text(face = "bold"))

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text: Slope Graph - Output

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Interpreting Slope Graphs

What Slope Graphs Reveal:


Treatment groups show mostly downward slopes

Most patients improved

Control group shows mixed results

Some up, some down (natural variation)

Individual variability is visible

Not all patients respond equally
Some non-responders in treatment groups

Response heterogeneity matters

Need to identify why some don’t respond


Advantage: Shows both group trend AND individual variation

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE

title: Time Series - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Common Mistakes


Over-smoothing - Losing important details

Solution: Try different span values

Too many lines on one plot

Solution: Use small multiples or filter

Ignoring uncertainty

Solution: Always show confidence intervals

Poor annotation placement

Solution: Use arrow() and adjust positions

Wrong baseline for percent change

Solution: Clearly document reference point

Missing time labels

Solution: Use clear date formats or labels

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text:
What We’ll Learn - Intermediate


Spatial Data Visualization:

Choropleth maps (filled regions)
Point/bubble maps
Heat maps (density)
Faceted maps (small multiples)
Interactive maps


Analytical Goals:

🟣 Geographic - Where things happen
🟡 Distribution - Spatial patterns
🟢 Ranking - Regional comparisons
⚫ Correlation - Geographic relationships

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Setup Code


Code
# Load required packages
library(readxl)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(sf)          # For spatial data
library(maps)        # For map data
library(viridis)     # For color scales

# Load dataset
health_data <- read_excel("../../data/PublicHealth_BP_Dataset.xlsx")

# Aggregate data by region
region_summary <- health_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(Region)) %>%
  group_by(Region) %>%
  summarise(
    mean_bp = mean(SysBP_0m, na.rm = TRUE),
    mean_cholesterol = mean(Cholesterol, na.rm = TRUE),
    mean_bmi = mean(BMI, na.rm = TRUE),
    n_patients = n(),
    hypertension_rate = mean(SysBP_0m >= 140, na.rm = TRUE) * 100
  )

# Create theme
theme_map <- function() {
  theme_void() +
  theme(
    text = element_text(family = "serif", size = 12),
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 11, hjust = 0.5),
    legend.position = "right",
    legend.title = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "aliceblue")
  )
}

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Choropleth Map - Code

Purpose: Show values across geographic regions using color
Goal: 🟣 Geographic + 🟢 Ranking


Code
# Get US state map data
us_states <- map_data("state")

# Create region to state mapping (simplified for demonstration)
region_states <- data.frame(
  region_name = c("North", "South", "East", "West"),
  states = c("new york,pennsylvania,ohio,michigan",
            "texas,florida,georgia,alabama",
            "massachusetts,connecticut,rhode island,maine",
            "california,oregon,washington,nevada")
)

# Expand and join
state_regions <- region_states %>%
  separate_rows(states, sep = ",") %>%
  rename(region_lower = states)

# Join with map data
map_data_full <- us_states %>%
  left_join(state_regions, by = c("region" = "region_lower")) %>%
  left_join(region_summary, by = c("region_name" = "Region"))

# Create choropleth map
ggplot(map_data_full, aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group, fill = mean_bp)) +
  geom_polygon(color = "white", size = 0.3) +
  coord_map("albers", lat0 = 39, lat1 = 45) +  # Albers projection
  scale_fill_viridis_c(
    option = "plasma",
    name = "Mean Systolic BP\n(mmHg)",
    na.value = "gray90",
    guide = guide_colorbar(
      barwidth = 1.5,
      barheight = 15,
      title.position = "top"
    )
  ) +
  labs(title = "Average Blood Pressure by Region",
       subtitle = "Darker colors indicate higher blood pressure",
       caption = "Data: PublicHealth BP Dataset") +
  theme_map()

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text: Choropleth Map - Output

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Interpreting Choropleth Maps


Key Features:

Color intensity = Value magnitude
Patterns reveal regional clustering
White borders separate regions
Gray indicates missing data

Best Practices:

Use sequential color scales for continuous data
Use diverging scales for data with meaningful midpoint
Limit to 5-7 color bins for categorical
Always include legend with units


Our Map Shows:

Geographic variation in BP

Clear regional differences

Hot spots identified

East region shows highest BP

Cool spots visible

West region shows lowest BP

Spatial patterns suggest

Possible lifestyle/environmental factors
Need for targeted interventions

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Point/Bubble Map - Code

Purpose: Show individual locations with value-sized markers
Goal: 🟣 Geographic + 🟡 Distribution


Code
# Create sample patient locations (simulated for demonstration)
set.seed(123)
patient_locations <- health_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(Region), !is.na(SysBP_0m)) %>%
  mutate(
    # Simulate coordinates within regions
    lat = case_when(
      Region == "North" ~ runif(n(), 40, 45),
      Region == "South" ~ runif(n(), 30, 35),
      Region == "East" ~ runif(n(), 39, 43),
      Region == "West" ~ runif(n(), 35, 42)
    ),
    lon = case_when(
      Region == "North" ~ runif(n(), -85, -75),
      Region == "South" ~ runif(n(), -100, -80),
      Region == "East" ~ runif(n(), -75, -70),
      Region == "West" ~ runif(n(), -125, -115)
    ),
    hypertensive = ifelse(SysBP_0m >= 140, "Yes", "No")
  ) %>%
  sample_n(200)  # Sample for clarity

# Create point map
ggplot() +
  geom_polygon(data = us_states, 
               aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group),
               fill = "white", color = "gray70") +
  geom_point(data = patient_locations,
            aes(x = lon, y = lat, color = hypertensive, size = SysBP_0m),
            alpha = 0.6) +
  coord_map("albers", lat0 = 39, lat1 = 45) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("No" = "#00A087", "Yes" = "#DC0000"),
                    name = "Hypertensive") +
  scale_size_continuous(range = c(1, 6), name = "Systolic BP\n(mmHg)") +
  labs(title = "Patient Locations by Blood Pressure Status",
       subtitle = "Point size = BP value | Color = Hypertension status (≥140 mmHg)",
       caption = "Sample of 200 patients") +
  theme_map()

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text: Point/Bubble Map - Output

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Interpreting Point/Bubble Maps

What Point Maps Show:


Exact locations of events/observations

Each point = one patient

Clustering patterns

Where do high-BP patients concentrate?
Red dots (hypertensive) cluster in certain areas

Spatial distribution

Uniform vs. clustered
Our data shows regional clustering

Multiple attributes simultaneously

Size = BP value
Color = hypertension status
Position = location


Advantage: Shows individual variation AND spatial pattern

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Heat Map (Density) - Code

Purpose: Show density/concentration of observations
Goal: 🟣 Geographic + 🟡 Distribution


Code
# Create density heat map
ggplot() +
  # Base map
  geom_polygon(data = us_states, 
               aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group),
               fill = "gray95", color = "white") +
  # Density contours
  stat_density_2d(data = patient_locations,
                 aes(x = lon, y = lat, fill = after_stat(level)),
                 geom = "polygon",
                 alpha = 0.5,
                 bins = 10) +
  # Overlay points
  geom_point(data = patient_locations,
            aes(x = lon, y = lat),
            size = 0.5, alpha = 0.3, color = "black") +
  coord_map("albers", lat0 = 39, lat1 = 45) +
  scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "inferno",
                      name = "Patient\nDensity") +
  labs(title = "Patient Density Heat Map",
       subtitle = "Darker areas show higher patient concentration",
       caption = "Contours show density levels") +
  theme_map()

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text: Heat Map (Density) - Output

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Interpreting Heat Maps


Heat Map Features:

Color intensity = Density
Contour lines = Density levels
Hot spots = High concentration
Cool areas = Low concentration

When to Use:

Many overlapping points
Want to show concentration
Exact locations less important than density
Identifying high-activity areas


Our Heat Map:

Clear hot spots in East

Highest patient density

Moderate density in North & South

Evenly distributed

Sparse areas in West

Lower patient numbers

Urban/rural patterns visible

Concentration suggests urban centers


Insight: Resources should focus on high-density areas

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Faceted Maps - Code

Purpose: Compare spatial patterns across categories
Goal: 🟣 Geographic + 🟢 Comparison


Code
# Create faceted map
ggplot() +
  geom_polygon(data = us_states, 
               aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group),
               fill = "white", color = "gray70") +
  geom_point(data = patient_locations,
            aes(x = lon, y = lat, color = hypertensive),
            size = 2, alpha = 0.6) +
  facet_wrap(~ TreatmentGroup, ncol = 2) +
  coord_map("albers", lat0 = 39, lat1 = 45) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("No" = "#00A087", "Yes" = "#DC0000"),
                    name = "Hypertensive") +
  labs(title = "Patient Distribution by Treatment Group",
       subtitle = "Geographic distribution across treatment assignments",
       caption = "Each panel shows one treatment group") +
  theme_map() +
  theme(
    strip.background = element_rect(fill = "gray90", color = "black"),
    strip.text = element_text(face = "bold", size = 10),
    legend.position = "bottom"
  )

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text: Faceted Maps - Output

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Interpreting Faceted Maps

Power of Faceted Maps:


Direct comparison across categories

Same scale enables comparison

Pattern differences immediately visible

Treatment allocation varies by region

Consistency checks

Is treatment assignment geographically balanced?

Multiple variables displayed

Location + Treatment + Hypertension status


Our Finding:

Treatment groups fairly balanced geographically
Hypertension prevalence similar across groups
Good randomization evident

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Interactive Maps (Conceptual)

Using Leaflet for Interactive Maps:


Code
library(leaflet)

# Create interactive map
leaflet(patient_locations) %>%
  addTiles() %>%  # Add OpenStreetMap tiles
  addCircleMarkers(
    ~lon, ~lat,
    radius = ~SysBP_0m / 20,  # Size by BP
    color = ~ifelse(hypertensive == "Yes", "red", "green"),
    fillOpacity = 0.6,
    popup = ~paste0(
      "<b>Patient ID:</b> ", PatientID, "<br>",
      "<b>Systolic BP:</b> ", SysBP_0m, " mmHg<br>",
      "<b>Region:</b> ", Region, "<br>",
      "<b>Hypertensive:</b> ", hypertensive
    )
  ) %>%
  addLegend(
    position = "bottomright",
    colors = c("green", "red"),
    labels = c("Normal BP", "Hypertensive"),
    title = "BP Status"
  )


Features: Zoom, pan, click for details, layer toggle

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Common Mistakes


Wrong projection

Solution: Use appropriate projection (Albers, Mercator, etc.)

Too many colors in choropleth

Solution: Limit to 5-7 bins, use sequential scales

Overlapping points obscure patterns

Solution: Use transparency, jittering, or heat maps

No context (missing borders/labels)

Solution: Add state/country borders, major cities

Color-blind unfriendly palettes

Solution: Use viridis, ColorBrewer palettes

Misleading scales

Solution: Show scale bar, use consistent scales across facets

title: Geographic - INTERMEDIATE
text:
Geographic Data Sources

Common Data Sources:


R packages: maps, rnaturalearth, tigris (US census)
Shapefiles: Government GIS data
APIs: Google Maps, OpenStreetMap
Coordinates: GPS, geocoding services

Data Requirements:

Choropleth: Region IDs matching map data
Point maps: Latitude and longitude
Heat maps: Many coordinate pairs
All: Consistent coordinate reference system (CRS)

Tip: Always verify coordinate system and projection!

title: Practical Application
text:
Case Study 1: Publication Figure
Scenario: Need publication-ready figure for medical journal
Requirements: - High resolution (300 DPI) - Grayscale-friendly - Clear statistical annotations - Professional formatting

title: Practical Application
text:
Publication Figure - Code


Code
# Treatment effect with confidence intervals
model <- lm(SysBP_12m ~ TreatmentGroup + Age + BMI_0m + SysBP_0m,
           data = health_data)

library(ggeffects)
effects <- ggpredict(model, terms = "TreatmentGroup")

p <- plot(effects) +
  labs(title = "Treatment Effect on Systolic Blood Pressure",
       subtitle = "Adjusted for age, BMI, and baseline BP",
       x = "Treatment Group",
       y = "Predicted Systolic BP (mmHg)",
       caption = "Error bars: 95% confidence intervals. n=500 per group.") +
  theme_bw(base_size = 12) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", hjust = 0),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    legend.position = "none"
  )

# Save high-res
ggsave("figure1.tiff", p, width = 7, height = 5, dpi = 300)
ggsave("figure1.eps", p, width = 7, height = 5, device = cairo_ps)

     gaugeSectors(success = c(80, 100), warning = c(60, 80),
